sections: A few weeks ago, I mentioned in passing that I was working on a new structure for this site. With that comes a set of deadlines that
get me to into a position where I could generate the sort of flow of posts here that I've aspired to for a long time.

Well, it's finally done, and will be launching later today. I'll make a more general post about it a week or two in, once I'm happy it's running the way I want it to. I'll explain the rationale in more detail then. For now, though, here's a preview for email subscribers
of what's coming. (I'm using Ghost's new ability to
on the web to do this…)
Here's the planned weekly minimum on the site:

A short explanation of something technical that you might need to know to do better journalism: SEO, social, multimedia and the like. Something defined, useful and actionable. Sometimes they'll be timely, like the one that will go out later today. And sometimes they'll just be useful.
A short, snappy digest of links to the things you might need to know as a working journalists: developments in search, social, audience strategy and journalism practice.
It'll be broken down clearly into sections, so you can find the ones that are relevant to you. And there will be no more than a sentence or two on each  link.
If it's a quiet week, it'll be short. If it's a busy one, it'll be longer. But it'll never be
(Temporary name while I think of something better. Suggestions desperately appreciated…)
I'll do at least one weekly analysis piece, either on a topical subject, or on some element of journalism or publishing practice that has been on my mind in recent days or weeks.
If this works, and I start to see a big enough uptick in subscribers, I'll start adding:
But let's not run before we walk!
It's possible, once I get into the swing of this, that I'll be doing other posts through the week as well. What I haven't decided yet is if I'm going to push
This is where I'd like to hear from you. Which would you prefer:
Everything I publish sent as emails
A weekly digest of posts I've published outside the structure outlined above?

At some point, elements of this will go behind the site paywall. I'm not sure which yet — I'll be looking at which elements convert best to new subscribers, and which elements get the most traction in open rates and traffic. But I'll be sure to warn non-paying subscribers before it happens.
So, that's the plan. What do you think?
